data.title: Good family operated Italian restaurant
data.text: Great service from a long established family business. Features home cooked Italian fare. Clientele is primarily local so has a friendly atmosphere . The food is good and prepared to order. I enjoyed the frog legs and homemade sphagetti the portions were good sized and the meals were reasonably priced. All in all still a great place.

data.title: Hidden Gem
data.text:
The great Italian place your grandparents may have eaten!
It is old old, small and a little cramped for space, but the food is well worth it. The tomato sauce is REAL thick and delicious. Bread sticks can be eaten by the dozen!  Don't forget to play a few tunes on the jukebox!

data.title: Superior Service
data.text: Good place to eat in pueblo. Great service, great food, great people to be around. Had a great experience at Latronicas.

data.title: Pricey for a neighborhood bar
data.text: Very loud bar atmosphere had to yell to have conversation. Sauce very salty. American beauty spagetti unless you pay $2 extra to get the handmade noodles. Drinks are small.  We had gin and tonic mostly ice. Pueblo natives voted it best of Pueblo in 2014 so must be something you grow up with. This is billed as original Italian food for me there are better places in Pueblo fir True Italian food. Will not be back.

data.title: Varies from one visit to another!
data.text: I have had really really good meals. However, I have had very average too!  --- I love the fact that the restaurant has brought our family so many memories over the years!  We probably will continue to frequent there when we are in town.

data.title: Home Style Pueblo Italian
data.text: Very traditional family restaurant.  Nice throw back look and feel.  Great service, decent menu offerings.  Friday spaghetti (mushrooms and butter) and cheese ravioli with sausage both very tasty and appetizing.  Banquet hall in back and plenty parking.  Will return, worth checking out if you are in Pueblo.

data.title: Nope
data.text:
We had a couple of La Tronica's vouchers from an online site. We should have read the TripAdvisor reviews before we went. We ordered something "safe"...we thought. Lasagna. First, we had never seen iceberg lettuce with Italian dressing and bleu cheese crumbles. What a waste of bleu cheese! The storebought bread was...well, just like storebought. Without being too descriptive:  the lasagna pasta was ok but under this was a solid slab of meat, like a huge tightly packed hamburger. Some kind of mystery meat that didn't taste like beef. It was something else more towards a liver pate taste. The sauce was tomatoe sauce from a can...no flavor (which at this point was a good-thing).
The service was ok. The atmosphere was something out of "Cheers" and the regulars and bartender were entertaining. But we decided to trade in our second voucher for La Tronica's.

data.title: La Tronicas is still open?
data.text:
My wife and I decided to give them one more try (last visit was in 1993) and nothing has changed. The pasta was way too soft, pasta sauce; well there's nothing to it-no flavor. The Lasagna is edible otherwise unremarkable. 
I don't know how this restaurant has survived with the (lack of) food quality they serve.

data.title: Rotten steak
data.text: They seriously sent a steak that smelled rotten to the table. When my husband asked me if I could smell it, I leaned a bit closer and it was BAD! The waitress rushed out and told my husband that the cook noticed it smelled rotten while he was cooking it and not to let my husband eat it. She brought him a new one which he ate. When he asked to talk to a manager, this rude lady came out, told him he ate a steak so there was no problem and that we were lying about the whole thing. Her words, "Things happen." Maybe the fact that we were the only people in the place at 6:30 on a Saturday evening should have warned us. Never going back to that nasty place again.

data.title: This restaurant is terrible
data.text: We stopped in for an authentic Italian meal. What a huge disappointment. The pasta noodles were over cook to the point of mush. The spaghetti sauce had no flavor. It tasted like it was poured right out of a large can of tomato sauce and the meatballs and sausage were extremely under cook. The fried chicken was over cooked. The pasta dishes at Fazoil's have more flavor. Don't waste your time or money this restaurant is worth driving past.

data.title: authentic italian and Pueblo land mark.
data.text: Stop in and see Frank, he has one of  the best clubs that throw back to old Pueblo and absolutely wonderful authentic Italian food.

data.title: Eat with the Locals
data.text: You haven’t experienced the flavor of Pueblo until you’ve been to La Tronica’s. This is an old family restaurant, has been here forever and is quintessential Pueblo. Natives talk about how the cook would come out and tell you to clean your plate. Today, they’re more polite, but just as eager to feed you and please you. Very friendly service. We had the lasagna. Wonderful! They have a full bar, too. The salad and the bread rolls were good, too. Good food, friendly service, the heart and soul of old Pueblo.

data.title: Average dining experience!
data.text: Aunt was always talking about this Itialian dining spot being her favorite so we thought we'd give it a try. I had Eggplant parmesania and it came with a small portion of spaghetti. Did not like it. The spaghetti tasted undercooked and I did not care too much for the sauce. The Eggplant however, was very good as it had a different sauce. My wife had Spaghetti with Italian saugage. She did not like the sauce either, and thought it was average. Dinner came with a small salad and what was to be a antipasto plate which turned out to be a pickle (sliced) and 4 cherry peppers. I thought the food was a bit pricy for pasta, Bread was good and the atmosphere was very nice and service was excellant.

data.title: doesn't live up to hype
data.text:
Historic place that many say you must try. I tried it but wasn't impressed with the food. The sauce tasted "burnt" to me. On food alone, I would give 2 stars.

The atmosphere was pretty cool though. Very old, not remodeled for 40 years, but a good feel for those who don't have to have brand new chain type restaurants.

data.title: Back in a time machine
data.text: Okay, okay, La Tranica's kitchen may not be staffed with new-age Italian wonder chefs, but the place is worth a visit if only to time-travel back to the days when Italian workers powered one of the West's biggest steel plants, the remnants of which sit just a couple blocks away. Neither the decor nor the menu have changed in decades, and that's a good thing. Grandmotherly types still toil in the kitchen, and some of the waitresses have been around for years. Be sure to order the homemade pasta, either with the tasty meatballs or stewed chicken, or the retro ground veal parmesan. Meals come with a -- retro again -- small antipasti plate, and iceberg salad. Sit in one of the booths in front by the bar (usually quite busy) to enjoy a decent cocktail or a glass of dago red, and play Dean Martin on the jukebox. A pleasant, if brief, time-travel experience indeed!

data.title: Italian specific to area
data.text: This was not my idea of great Italian the spagetti tastes like American beauty with tomatoes on it.  Not very flavorful.  the fried chicken was greasy and bland.

data.title: local hangout
data.text: Great place to be seen.  Good martini but food average

data.title: Old Pueblo
data.text: I like the raviolis.  Be prepared to wait if you go late for dinner

data.title: Bad bad bad
data.text: Not even sure why the call themselves a restaurant. Terrible sauce on over priced spaghetti.

data.title: Good food, good service
data.text: If in Pueblo and don't want to always eat on the River Walk this is a good stop, wonderful menu, good value. You won't leave hungry.
